section.title: Angina 1: ED Care
section.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts. All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction. Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Ischemic Heart Disease, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/CD/ihd/ Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section. The intent of this use case is to capture actions that commonly occur when a patient presents with unstable angina. Many of the steps in this use case occur concurrently in an emergent case. In similar scenarios, the same actions may occur in slightly different order. Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter. Hyperlinks are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case. Hyperlinks suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

formalpara.title: Patient
formalpara.para: A person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

formalpara.title: Provider
formalpara.para: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). All are skilled health-care professionals trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Registration Clerk (Reg. Clerk)
formalpara.para: A hospital employee that collects demographic, insurance and “reason for visit” information from a new patient and enters this information in to the Admission/Discharge/Transfer (ADT) system and/or the electronic health record (EHR).

formalpara.title: Triage Nurse (Triage RN)
formalpara.para: A licensed nurse that assesses symptoms, health-related complaints, and vital signs to determine the degree of urgency for care.

formalpara.title: Unit Clerk (UC)
formalpara.para: A hospital employee that performs administrative duties to facilitate workflow and patient care in the emergency department (ED) or a nursing unit.

formalpara.title: Emergency Department Technician (ED Tech)
formalpara.para: A hospital employee that is trained to provide basic tasks such as vital signs and laboratory draws under the supervision of an RN or Provider.

formalpara.title: Registered Nurse (RN)
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that is trained to provide nursing care to patients in inpatient and outpatient settings, within their defined scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Licensed Social Worker (LSW)
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that assists patients to improve their quality of life and social needs, and facilitates care after discharge.

formalpara.title: Nurse’s Aide/Assistant (NA)
formalpara.para: A trained healthcare worker that provides assistance with patient care, under the supervision of an RN.

formalpara.title: Clinical Pharmacist
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that often collaborates with physicians and other healthcare professionals to coordinate pharmaceutical interventions and promote health and disease prevention within their scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Dispensing Pharmacist
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that dispenses medications, monitors medication parameters and potential drug interactions, and provides information about medications, within their scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Radiology Technician (Rad Tech)
formalpara.para: A licensed radiography professional that performs diagnostic imaging exams on patients to help physicians assess illness and injury.

formalpara.title: Radiologist
formalpara.para: A licensed physician that specializes in diagnosing and treating diseases and injuries by using medical imaging.

formalpara.title: EKG Technician (EKG Tech)
formalpara.para: A cardiology technologist that administers basic electrocardiogram tests to patients. The results are then read by a cardiologist or other licensed physician.

formalpara.title: Respiratory Therapist (RT)
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare practitioner that provides care and treatment to patients requiring breathing and oxygenation support.

formalpara.title: Charge RN
formalpara.para: A registered nurse that is responsible for the efficient management of a nursing unit or department, including admissions, discharges, and the oversight of all nursing and support staff.

section.title: Description
section.para: 53 year old white male presents to the ED with chest pain and is diagnosed as having a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

listitem.para: Patient is brought to the ED by their family member
Patient is experiencing crushing chest pain (radiating to their jaw and neck), shortness of breath (dyspnea), nausea, and sweating (diaphoresis) after attempting to shovel their front walkway.
Patient has a history of stable angina that is usually relieved by rest, however the above symptoms worsened with rest.
Patient has taken one sublingual (SL) nitroglycerin (NTG) tablet, without relief.
Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical terminology.
EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.
